Explanations about Options.-i(M):
Selects the file from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication
 is read. This option is directly passed to ssh(1).

Explanations about Options.-P(M):
The -P option is equivalent to --partial --progress. Its purpose is to make it
 much easier to specify these two options for a long transfer that may be
 interrupted.
Explanations about Options.-e(C): The command would look like this "rsync -rP -e ssh username@serveraddress:"directory/file" /destinationfolder/" the r is for recursive downloads if you need a folder, the capital P is so that you can resume what had failed or been stopped prematirely and the "e ssh" tells rsync to comunicate over ssh.
Explanations about Options.-e(M):
This option allows you to choose an alternative remote shell program to use for
 communication between the local and remote copies of rsync. Typically, rsync is
 configured to use ssh by default, but you may prefer to use rsh on a local network.
Explanations about Options.-r(M): This tells rsync to copy directories recursively. See also --dirs (-d).

Explanations about Options.-i(M): Turns off interactive prompting during multiple file transfers.
Explanations about Options.-n(M):
Restrains ftp from attempting “auto-login” upon initial connection. If auto-login is
 enabled, ftp will check the .netrc (see netrc(5)) file in the user's home directory
 for an entry describing an account on the remote machine. If no entry exists, ftp
 will prompt for the remote machine login name (default is the user identity on the
 local machine), and, if necessary, prompt for a password and an account with which to
 login.
